description:
The RTX 5080 is a strong-performing GPU - to a point. It offers significant value advantages over RTX 4090 and RTX 5090 - but it's nowhere near as fast as either of them. Meanwhile, performance gains over the outgoing RTX 4080 Super are variable but never transformative. DLSS 4 multi frame generation is a nice-to-have feature - but comparisons against RTX 4090 with standard frame-gen show mixed results with latency. Rich has the complete lowdown.

A vast range of further benchmarks to explore in our Eurogamer web review: https://www.eurogamer.net/digitalfoundry-2025-nvidia-geforce-rtx-5080-review

Want some DF-branded tee-shirts, mugs, hoodies and various items based on DF lore? Check out our store: https://store.digitalfoundry.net

Join the DF Supporter Program for pristine video downloads, behind the scenes content, early access to DF Retro, early access to DF Direct Weekly and much, much more: https://bit.ly/3jEGjvx

Subscribe for more Digital Foundry: http://bit.ly/DFSubscribe

Kena 50s 3060, 3070 80s 1440p

F1 60s 3060, 3070 100 1440p

New world 1440p 3060 70s, 3070 100

Flight sim 1440p, 3060 40s, 3070 60s

Forza 3070 4k 100,3080 130 on average 

Hitman 3070 60s 4k, 3080 80s

4060 4K tsunama at 25 fps, 4070 40s no DLSS 

Elden Ring no DLSS 1440p, 4060 40 fps, 4070 70
 
 
  4080 Forza 4080 110 fps, 4080 140 4K

Avatar 4k 50fps 4080, 4090 70

Hogwarts 4080 4k 45s, 60 4090
 
As you guys can see, I compared models directly under a higher class, as that's the only way it makes a higher class worth it since the jump will be bigger, which is why it makes no sense to compare a 4090 to a 5090 or 5080 to 4080 only 1 gen apart. It only makes sense to compare the 4080 to the 5090, which will skip the 4080s; this way it shows a good jump. The same goes for coming from a card like mine, 4070, to the 5080 or 4060 to 5070.

See how you guys are all comparing the wrong models

comments.text:
I'm disappointed you didn't dive in to how this SKU should be sold (at best!) as "5070", based on historic scaling of actual hardware inside the thing relative to the flagship, and how this is clearly phase 2 of what they tried last time with the "4080 12GB" in terms of their main focus of the entire generation being trying to get away with charging more for less, instead of focussing on the technology itself.

Focussing only on the fps with MFG is pointless! Latency is obviously vital, but you also need to spend time talking about all the artefacts, shimmering, fuzziness that unavoidably comes with it. These frames are not equal! MFG is useless given it only helps if you're already at a smooth experience without it; even more useless than original FG was, given that suffered the same constraint, but MFG amplifies it.

The Hardware Unboxed boys have overtaken you in technical depth analysis. Come on, Rich! I expect more from former '90s game journos! Look at Mr Biffo! Look at Brooker! You can do it! All the turd polishing you're doing in this video is pretty demeaning; way too much "but it's still good value even if it's only 0.01% better than before!!!!!!!1".

comments.text: why benchmark it in performance mode? You should of set it to quality mode. I have the latest Nvidia driver installed. Tested my Aorus Master 4080 on 13900k with a OLED G9 95SC 2023 monitor on both CyberPunk and Alan Wake with DLSS4 and everything maxed out. In CyberPunk which has the new transformative (DLSS4), on the hardware/software I was getting 45 fps but it I could see everything including further distance like before with gorgeous visuals. Guess what? CyberPunk was very smooth gameplay! No latency lag, input lag, none of that! On Alan Wake 2, with DLSS4 on everything on max in Quality mode, (something i couldnt run at ALL before in DLSS 3.5 when I was getting 15-30 fps)I was getting 70 FPS STABLE!!!!  Which means there is a major improvement. Now the LCD Harware and FPS counter i think it has bugs. There is no way that both games run super smooth in a 5k pixel monitor(5120x1440p) with HDR10+, DLSS4, and everything maxed out! So if a 5080 is between 13-16% better than a 4080, that means youll likely see between 86-100 fps in Alan Wake 2 in my settings. I tested today and confirmed. I dont have a 50 Aorus series card but when i do, trust me im pushing it to the max. Let me know guys  if you want me to record a video and I will show you.

comments.text:
When a new NVIDIA card comes out and they stop selling their old cards it creates a bad situation.

One. Reference card prices are only available for a short time. Unless you're lucky you never get a card at that price. You're still paying a 20% premium over an advertised price for another vender. This is the car dealership model. Reviewers benchmark these cards but only advertise reference prices. For the most part, you're not going to get the card at that price.

Two. Even though A 4080 Super is close to a 5080, you can't buy that card for less. Using eBay's Terapeak research tool the average used price, not new but used, is $1102 in the US for the last 90 days. Even if you think, well I'll just get the older card at a discount for my upgrade. It doesn't work that way since you can't buy the old card new anymore and the used ones are being sold for large markups, usually more than new. You are again, only lucky to get a deal. Or you have to try to get the 5080 reference card. Good luck.

Three. The only way to get a big enough discount on an upgrade is if you wait 3-4 generations. By then, the newest games require much higher specs or technology to run well. Of course, that tech is only on the new cards. I know not everyone wants the best of the best or can afford it. But most people want to upgrade their GPU sooner than a new console comes out. That's kind of the point of PC gaming.

NVIDIA GPU's are just a racket now. Yes you can buy AMD or Intel but neither compete at the highest end. If they do, it's mainly in raster and not in ray-tracing and frame gen.

comments.text:
The thing that concerns me, is that all of the resources in these chunky, expensive cards, seems to be going towards expensive Ray Tracing and Path Tracing and I honestly cannot say the games look THAT much better for it (if at all, in some cases).

To me, if anything, games are looking less pretty and less creative in art direction.

There was something about the baked in lighting and cube maps that just gave the older games more pop to me.

I know developers are looking to save time and money, but it just feels like power down the drain with these cards, including their draw.

Look at some of these numbers, over 400 watts of power draw?????

Again, it's not even like the games are looking THAT good.

I don't know about anyone else, but the first thing I notice about any game are textures, asset quality, god rays and weather effects, more than any other effects on the screen.  I don't care much for ambient occlusion and precision of cast lighting and shadows.  The biggest upgrade to lighting for me was when they started giving us volumetric lighting from street lamps etc, which doesn't even require ray tracing.

Without the implementation of things that immediately catch the human eye first, there's no point increasing resolution on your screen.  In fact, art style done well enough doesn't even require high resolutions, how did we cope with 480i back in the day?  It's because the art style, visuals and the colours used to pop out of your screen, the clarity of the image was just a bonus.

I just don't like where all this is heading, games are looking comparatively worse tech for tech, than they did in 5th and 6th gen in my opinion.

It's difficult to say any game out there right now is compelling you towards a $1,000+ graphics card upgrade.
comments.author: @Longlostpuss

comments.text: While doing DF interview with Nvidia, they stated that the base FPS requirement for MFG is the same as 2x FG, I think that is not the case. Yes, there are obviously latency issue, but even ignoring that, the image quality issue, mainly the artifacts, will be a lot more noticeable when using MFG at lower base FPS vs 2x FG. If for example you're fine using 2x FG with 40FPS base FPS, when you enable MFG, yes, you can get 160FPS, but compared to 80FPS with 2x FG, MFG will be smoother but pretty noticeable artifacting. I think for MFG you really need to be at minimum 60FPS and preferably above not only because of the latency issue but because image quality. This obviously will also depends if the game is slow paced (which if slow paced then why you use MFG in the first place?) or fast paced and your tolerance not only to latency but to image artifacts. Again, higher base latency is not just about latency but also image quality. The higher the base FPS is, the difference between the real frames will be smaller. Smaller difference between real frames means less chance for artifacts which obviously will be important for MFG since you will see 3 generated frames every 1 real frame.

@zachb1706  It's not LITERALLY a 5070, it's functionally a 5070 based on the ratio of performance vs the top card in the stack.

The performance gap between the 1080/1080ti, 2080/2080ti, 3080/3090, and 4080/4090 is 30% or less, whereas the gap from the 70 class product to the top product in each generation is closer to 50%. comments.text:
I don’t see it as complacency, there’s only so much performance you can get. The rendering pipeline is already incredibly optimised, the architecture is already near its limit. Nvidia really can only improve through cheaper  transistor prices which have stopped dropping (a big reason is because of TSMCs monopoly).

So really they can only improve through AI, and they’ve built their hardware around it. For now, we’re hearing rumours Nvidia is looking to move away from TSMC.
comments.author: @zachb1706

comments.text: @zachb1706  I don't know how you can't see this as complacency... at least to some degree. I'm not saying there aren't other factors, but they stuck with the same process node and are selling people a "new" generation of cards that are really just marginal improvements on the old generation, outside of the 5090. This is exactly the crap that got Intel in trouble and AMD is releasing on a new node, not that it's going to help their situation, but this narrative that "what else could they do" is crap. Besides, JayzTwoCents has said the MFG on the 5080 is gross and unusable. So, the AI features might not be worth a damn and you can use the new transformer DLSS model on the 20 series. I'm just not seeing an upside here, and it's not because they couldn't, it's because they didn't want to and would rather focus their efforts on the AI garbage that is making them money and try to use it as a band aid to try to cover up how poor they are compared to the previous models, and it doesn't even really improving anything. If MFG sucks on the 5080, it's only going to get worse going down the stack.
comments.author: @TheGameBench

comments.text: @ no, AMD is on the same node. And AMD could deliver a massive improvement, their architecture is way behind Nvidia’s. But the fact they aren’t even competing at the top end tells me they aren’t going to do that.

comments.text: @zachb1706  No... they aren't. This is easily found on Google. RDNA3 was on a 6/5nm process where RDNA4 is on a 4nm process. They are different nodes. As to the rest, I never argued otherwise.

comments.text:
@TheGameBench  on TSMC’s own website:
“The 4nm (N4) process technology is an enhanced version of 5nm (N5) technology”
They did this for 7nm as well, N6 was just an optimised 7nm process

I have been saying for weeks if you sell your 4090 for a 5090, fine, that's up to you, but if you have plans to sell your 4090 for a 5080, don't. 
The 4090 beats the 5080 unless it uses MFG x3/x4. From what I have seen of x4, it's a no-go; x3 seems ok at a push. Add to that the Vram issue. If you like adding on 4k texture mods, a 5080 is not going to last.

The better news is that DLSS 4 has killed any thoughts of upgrading to a 5000. Say you had a game, Cyberpunk, and you played it maxed out/quality DLSS 3, well, you can now play it with DLSS 4 on balance, gain frames, and it looks better than quality did.

If you rock a 4090, save your money, buy other parts, or start saving for the 6000s.

comments.text: @tomalexander4327  Yes, but there are limits. There is an inherrent latency to all FG, since they use interpolation.  You have to wait for a second frame to be generated. Then you have to delay that frame while you create the interpolated frames, display those frames, then display the final delayed frame.  Even with say MFG x4 - at 60fps base framerate,  assume instant Interpolated frame generation, and no regard for frame pacing, you still would have a theorhetical minimal increase to input lag of 12ms (3x4ms for each gen'd frame, assuming at 240fps output framerate).  Assuming you had perfect input latency of only the single frame @ 60fps of 16ms, then adding another 12ms ontop of that, means an 66% increase in latency.   None of this is practically achievable no matter how good the tech, so those numbers in reality will always be higher.  So it is worth noting, if you are trying to get your frames to the screen ASAP to minimize latency, delaying the next frame, until after you have both interpolated and displayed 3 extra frames, is going to add some appreciable, unavoidable delay.

comments.text:
I do agree that it functions more like a 70-class card now, but it's really hard to do an apples-to-apples comparison. First, the 90-class didn’t even used to exist. The 3090 was massively overpriced, while the 4090 was actually a "good deal" by comparison. Then, relative to that, the 5090 has increased in  its's price to performance nearly linearly compared to 4090, which somewhat affects the way the 5080 is viewed. Moreover, the 5080 hasn’t increased in price compared to the 4080 (especially the original 4080, which was overpriced, especially relative to the 3080!). I do agree with the thrust of your point, though – but it’s all a bit murky from generation to generation.

Also, in regards to inflation, the main issue with the shifting tier price/performance and cost increases is, as Rich has pointed out many times before, that smaller and smaller process nodes aren't getting cheaper. It's becoming increasingly difficult to shrink the node without the costs either remaining static or even increasing. This is why the 5090, with more silicon, costs proportionally more. It's not general inflation at play here, but rather industry-specific cost increases due to the challenges of advancing semiconductor manufacturing.
